text: 6-Mute English from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello, this is 6-minute English from BBCLearningEnglish. I'm Phil.
And I'm Georgie.
speaker: Phil

text: If you ask a woman, ‘Are you eating for two
speaker: eating for two

text: The phrase has a very specific meaning.
You're asking, are you pregnant?
And like many of the idioms we commonly use in English,
this phrase contains a little bit of truth.
A pregnant woman really is eating for two,
herself and the baby growing inside her.
The female human body is amazing.
During pregnancy, it protects the growing baby
by allowing it to take whatever nutrients it needs from the mother.
This means it's the mum to be, not the baby,
who experiences any nutritional problems.
It's also the reason why it's so important that pregnant women
In this programme, we’ll be finding out
speaker: Phil

text: how a woman's relationship to food changes during pregnancy.
And as usual, we'll be learning some useful new vocabulary too.
But first, I have a question for you, Phil.
For some pregnant women, finding reliable information
on what food to eat can be hard.
Finding out about harmful foods to avoid on the other hand is much easier.
So, according to NHS recommendations,
which of these foods should pregnant women not eat?
Is it A, chips, B, oily fish, or C, smoked salmon?
I think the answer is C, smoked salmon.
speaker: Georgie

text: Okay, Phil, we'll find out the correct answer at the end of the programme.
Although eating healthy and nutritious food is important for mums and babies,
speaker: Georgie

text: the story gets complicated because of the changes
a woman's body goes through during pregnancy.
Here's Jagger Wise, presenter of BBC Radio 4's The Food programme,
reporting on her experience of pregnancy.
I feel like throughout this pregnancy, my body is just gone a bit haywire
and there are things that my body is doing.
That's frankly weird.
Nose bleeds is a really good example.
Yeah, I can count the amount of nose bleeds pre-pregnancy I've had on one hand,
and now I seem to get them all the time.
Jagger says that during pregnancy, her body went haywire.
It stopped working properly.
speaker: haywirecount the number ofon one hand count the number of something on one hand

text: For example, she had lots of nose bleeds, whereas before being pregnant,
she could count the number of nose bleeds she had on one hand.
The idiom to count the number of something on one hand
emphasises that this doesn't happen very often,
or that there's a small number of something.
After all, you can only count to five on one hand,
many pregnant women experience cravings.
The strong desire for some particular food,
anything from ice cream to sardines.
When these cravings offer food that's not so healthy,
some women feel guilty, thinking, I know I should be eating healthy,
but all I want is chips.
Here's Jagger Wise again, speaking with nutritional therapist Henrietta Wilson,
on the best way to deal with guilty feelings.
How guilty should you feel…
speaker: binge

text: It's more the question.
For that late night chocolate binge,
when your body is telling you, you need cake.
Listen, I think the most important thing is to not get out the cast of nintails,
is to absolutely be kind to yourself.
Particularly in that first trimester, it is a very critical window,
but at the same time, it can be the time when all you want to do is to eat chips,
because your body is going through what it perceives to be physiological stress.
So it's doing the best that you can, and it's absolutely not about giving yourself a hard time.
Jagger's food cravings led to a chocolate binge.
A binge is an occasion where you do something in an extreme way,
speaker: binge.binge

text: like eating or drinking too much.
Henrietta's advice is to not use the catternine tails.
In the past, the catternine tails was a whip made of nine strings,
which was used to punish prisoners.
Nowadays, when someone talks about the catternine tails,
they are probably talking about the ways people sometimes use to punish themselves
if they feel guilty.
But, says Henrietta, pregnancy isn’t about giving yourself a hard time
speaker: giving yourself a hard time

text: treating itself badly or criticising yourself.
Pregnancy is a special time of life, and all a baby can ask if the mum does her best,
and of course avoids some foods, which reminds me of your question, Georgie.
Which food does the NHS recommend pregnant women do not eat?
I guess it was smoked salmon.
Which was the correct answer?
Smoked salmon is best avoided because of the risk of bacteria,
but oily fish is good, and even a bowl of chips now and then are fine.
Right, let's recap the vocabulary we've learned in the program.
Starting with the idiom, eating for two, which means to be pregnant.
If something goes haywire it stops working properly or becomes difficult to control.
speaker: haywire

text: If you say you could count something on one hand,
you're emphasising that something does not happen very often,
or that there are only a few of those things.
A binge is an occasion when you do something to excess,
speaker: binge

text: For example, eat, drink, or spend money.
In the past, the catanine tails was a whip used to punish prisoners,
but nowadays it usually refers to the ways in which someone criticises themselves as a form of self-punishment.
And finally, to give yourself a hard time
speaker: give yourself a hard time

text: means to treat yourself badly by criticising or blaming yourself.
